text: We'll hear argument now in Number oh oh ten eighty-nine, Toyota Motor Manufacturing versus Ella Williams.
Thank you, Mister Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
limitation...

can I just ask if at at the outset, so you have plenty of time to comment on there's expert testimony, as I read the briefs, that on your opponent's side that she's suffers a lack of access to the labor market from fifty to fifty-five percent of the jobs, both nationwide and in Kentucky.
A a number of things about that.
When you say it was rejected by the district court, you don't mean it was inadmissible.
The the district court considered it and said it was not probative of what it purported to show, a loss of access to the job market.

Mr. Roberts, in the same vein as Justice Stevens' question, how does the worker's compensation notion of disability fit in? As I understand it, she was assessed as having a twenty percent what was it partial disability for worker's compensation purposes.
B- but but pursuant to very different standards.
Why wouldn't twenty percent limitation twenty percent occupational impairment be a substantial limitation?
Well, first of all, it may be pertinent if the standards were the same, but only under the working category.
Why why did the court of appeals avoid addressing the work approach? It was it because it thought this Court had rejected that?
Well, a couple of reasons.
Should we address that, or because it was not addressed below, leave that alone?
Well, I think the the more typical approach would be not to address the major life activity of working since it was not addressed below, except to this extent.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: This case is not about the inability to perform a single job.
Mr. Rosenbaum, so far as the question presented here is, do you are you would defend the Sixth Circuit's opinion?
I defend the result, Mr. Chief Justice.
But not the reasoning?
Not in its entirety, but part of it I do.
Well, where do you disagree?
I disagree when the Sixth Circuit says that after you determine an individual is substantially limited, you must go farther and that individual must show that their limitation affects their work.
